body: I merged this and rebuilt the web rebuild since I had another change of my own that required a web site rebuild. Just thought I'd save one of us the trouble of a web site rebuild.

What is the intent behind this change? Is it to just accept the syntax?

If it is intended to be the full feature, there should be some tests added that demonstrate that the feature works.
The manuals should be updated. Perhaps you could write a separate JIRA for that purpose? @liuyu000 might be interested.
@mashengchen, @selvaganesang, @venkat1m:  Where does this change stand? Is it ready for merging? Does it require more work?

Do you know whether the old behavior of TEST037 just masked errors and looked like success or whether the statements using reserved words really succeeded? Having too many reserved words is one of the biggest complaints of new Trafodion users, so increasing the number of reserved words would not be good.

I think @anoopsharma00 made some changes a while ago that moved many keywords from the reserved to the non-reserved category.

The old behavior of TEST037 was an artifact of turning off reserved word checking in some code paths. Notice in the old expected results, the comments say, "expect error 3128" but no error occurs. (See the code change to common/NAString.cpp. The old code for function IsSqlReservedWord formerly returned FALSE. I've changed it to call the ComResWords methods instead. Actually there is a derived product that also calls the ComResWords methods here, so I believe this is correct.)

+1
Thanks for the explanation. Now you got me thinking what that "derived product" might be :-)
Note: There is also static SQL code remaining in ustat/hs_cli.cpp and ustat/hs_globals.cpp. This code will be removed in a later set of changes.
@svarnau, what's the state of this change? Should this pull request be closed or are you still working on it?
I'm not currently working on this. Hoping that @traflm can get a chance to try out python-installer on centos7.
Hi, Dave.Thanks for reminding. I have wrote a JIRA TRAFODION-3127.
FYI: Ran full regressions on this change last night on a workstation. They pass.
@DaveBirdsall Thanks for your remiding, I'll update the SQL Reference Manual 😁

I presume that  there is no need for  Trafodion SQL engine to parse the Hbase options because the engine doesn't do any specific action based on these options.  If so,  Hbase create options could have been implemented like pass thru.  If there is a problem with hbase create options pass through string, hbase would return an error. Trafodion can just return an error and with DDL transactions enabled automatically, the transaction is rolled back to ensure the metadata consistency. This way, there is no need to update Trafodion code for any new options.

@selvaganesang , this is only for user friendly. By default, Trafodion will NOT take any assumption of what HBase options to use. All these CQD by default is null.
At field, when user want to create a table, in most cases, they have to explicitly specify three HBASE_OPTIONS. We saw them in nearly 100% use cases. 
It is hard for end user, or even experienced supporting engineers to remember these details. And since it is Trafodion extension, many times, we have to change existing tools to add these options syntax.
With these three CQDs, it will help in above use cases. And it doensn't change default behavior, so user use it with clear understanding of what they want the table with hbase options.
This is a pure user-friendly improvements.

@traflm My suggestion is to have a single CQD that would let users to specify the default hbase options. Then Trafodion uses it in create table,  Trafodion could validate the CQD at the time of issuing the CQD by creating a dummy table with these hbase options.
